This license does not transfer any rights regarding material used in the edition by permission of a third party. 2006 Civil War correspondence, 1862-1864 Anderson, William B. (b. 1822) Twenty-one handwritten letters, 4 documents, and 1 CD-ROM. The W. B. Anderson Collection is the property of the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library of The Ohio State University Libraries. Any use of the material should acknowledge such ownership. The Ohio State University holds copyright to all images of manuscript pages used in the edition. Salutation from letter of 27 June 1862 Salutation from letter of 27 June 1862 Letter Call no. Salutation from letter of 27 June 1862 In some ways, William B. Anderson's short letter of 27 June 1862 to his wife, Mary Louisa, typifies the twenty-one letters from William to Louisa that survive in the collection of the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at The Ohio State University. It addresses three of the four broad topics about which he repeatedly writes to his wife during the summers of 1862, 1863, and 1864: managing domestic affairs and sustaining familial bonds when family members are separated for long periods by great distances; the rhetoric and logistics of mid-nineteenth-century correspondence; and the economic, logistical, and physical challenges of the riverboat business, especially on a waterway as critical as the Ohio River in the midst of the American Civil War (in other letters, Anderson also reflects more broadly on the uncertainties, vicissitudes, and suffering faced by civilians and soldiers alike in wartime). However, this letter is also unique. All but two of the letters were written from Cincinnati, a thriving center of commerce on the Ohio River approximately halfway between its source at the confluence of the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and its confluence with the Mississippi River a mile or so south of Cairo, Illinois. The remaining letter in the collection was written from St. Louis, Missouri—though Anderson mentions writing from Louisville, Kentucky and Nashville, Tennessee as well. This letter was written from Pittsburgh, William and Louisa's home town. Presumably, he had been visiting his family and had expected to leave Pittsburgh by the Friday in late June when he wrote the letter; he writes to inform his wife of a delay. As the collection in general reveals, delays were common, caused variously by negotiations over freight, water levels on the river, mechanical difficulties, and various military complications. Arrangements regarding freight seem to have kept Anderson in Pittsburgh overnight on June 27. He wants to secure a full load before leaving Pittsburgh because he "cannot depend upon getting any freight below here." He takes the opportunity to ask Louisa to send down "the Can of milk and 2 jars of lard and my clothes and overcoat." The definite article stands out: the Can of milk. One wonders whether, in his habitual haste (on which he often blames poor spelling and handwriting), he has simply rushed off and forgotten these items, and Louisa has sent him a note asking what she should do with them. In any case, in his haste to send her instructions, he crosses out the next two lines of his letter and recomposes them. Characteristically, the life of a riverboat captain seems frenetic. It is also worth noting that he arranges to convey a note to his wife via "some one on the Shore at Shousetown." While the Andersons clearly handled much of their correspondence through the U.S. mail (he mentions post offices several times, and the collection includes one stamped envelope), they often convey both messages and goods through intermediaries traveling by rail or river. Anderson's closing request constitutes something of a refrain in the letters. He asks Louisa to call on a Mr. Russell (probably John Russell, a local merchant) in order to collect money owed him, noting that he must meet his obligations on the crew's upcoming payday. Aside from suggesting that riverboat captains had to watch their cash flow carefully, this request reminds us that Louisa played a key role not only in caring for the Anderson household, including their four children (a fifth would be born in 1865), but also in tending to their business interests. Though we have only William Anderson's side of the correspondence, the letters reveal many details of Louisa's everyday life as well. It is Louisa, presumably, whom we have to thank for initially preserving the letters, probably for the very common, personal reasons to which David Levy alludes in Scrolling Forward: Making Sense of Documents in the Digital Age: "In the privacy of our own homes we are likely to hold on to any number of treasures: cards, letters, and notes written long ago, photographs, scrapbooks filled with mementoes from an earlier era. We can't throw them out, even if we can't say why. We may look at them rarely or not at all, yet still it is somehow comforting to know they are there. It's as if something of importance is embedded in their very substance. This has less to do with their information content per se than with the emotions they evoke and the personal relationships they signify and embody" (96–97). The Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at The Ohio State University purchased the letters in part because they fit into a larger goal of acquiring materials that reveal the "common man's view of great events," and war letters are one focus of that larger effort (Smith). The collection as a whole, and the letter of 27 June 1862 more specifically, should also prove interesting to business historians and students of letter writing in American culture (Hewitt). The passing of time has made the everyday information in the letters newly valuable, though the letters also retain the power Levy speaks of to evoke the emotional fabric of everyday life, especially when it becomes frayed in the course of great events. Places Mentioned in the Text Louisville In his letter of June 16, Anderson notes that he did not write to Louisa during a previous stop in Louisville, KY. This edition represents a series of letters that William B. Anderson wrote to his wife, Louisa, at the time of the Civil War. During the war, Anderson piloted steam ships along the Ohio River, carrying freight and passengers alike. At this time, letter writing was the most effective means of communication, and the only way to keep domestic affairs in order. The collection of letters penned by Anderson was purchased by the Ohio State Rare Books and Manuscripts library. They purchased the letters in an effort to increase their collection of wartime letters as well as documents that better illustrate the life-world of the historical periods that the letters were written in. The reason for digitizing these documents is that the editors are trying to make these documents as easily accessible to as many people as possible. These letters may be of intest to historians interested in the Civil War, the Steamship Industry, or even postal historians. These potential readers were given the most careful consideration in designing the digital texts. The hope is that by making these annotated and edited documents available on the world wide web, that the documents will be "streamlined and tailored in the service of ever greater efficiency" (Levy 69). Hopefully, the rich media and annotations provided will help make these documents more easily understood while the technology itself makes them more widely available to interested audiences. Encoding of the Anderson letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription, with supplemental information allowing for semi-modernized, corrected, regularized, or expanded views included as the values of attributes associated with various elements. Accordingly, abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underscoring, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed or tagged as they appear in the original manuscripts. Regularized versions of all names and referring strings have been encoded as the values of "reg" attributes. Standard format values for all dates have been encoded in "value" attributes. Corrections and emendations in Anderson's hand have been encoded as cancelations and interlinear or marginal additions. In a few cases, omitted text has been supplied by the editors for the sake of clarity and encoded with the TEI element. The following structural elements of the letters are also encoded: opener (including salutation and dateline), body, lines, paragraphs, pages, and closers (including salutation and signature). Notes and postscripts are identified as such. The critical apparatus used in particular views of the letters is explained at the bottom of each view. The XML and XSL files related to this edition are all available in the KB. The XML files that constitute this edition of the William B. Anderson letters are named according the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: WBA_YYYYMMDD.xml. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars. If the year, month, or date on which a letter was written could not be determined, the appropriate part of the filename is rendered with 0s. XSL style sheet documents are named with the prefix "WBA" followed by an underscore and a descriptive phrase (e.g., "WBA_diplomatic.xsl). To facilitate embedding or linking to image, audio, and video files, this edition supplements the Text Encoding Initiative's DTD by adding a URL attribute to the element and an MMID (i.e., Media Manager ID) attribute to the element. The values of the MMID attribute in elements and the file IDs in the URL attribute of elements that link to, or embed, image, audio, and video files contained in the Media Manager are generated by the Media Manager application. Anderson (1822-1897) were married September 15, 1853 in Cincinnati, Ohio. They had five children. History of Allegheny County (298). Letter from William B. Anderson to his Wife, Louisa, 16 June 1862 Anderson, William B. USA Columbus, OH Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University William B. Anderson Collection SPEC.RARE.CMS.0309 William B. Anderson writes home to his wife, Louisa, from Cincinnati, Ohio. He is hauling Coal Boat men from Louisville, Kentucky. While in Cincinnati, Anderson visits his mother-in-law, the 'old lady,' as well as family friends. During the dry, dusty, June weather, a fire breaks out near the Ohio River and Third St, destroying several houses. He opens his riverboat up as an improptu shelter for the fire victims, even filling the typically unoccupied Ladies' Cabins. Anderson closes the letter by inviting Louisa to accompany him on his next trip to Cincinnati. William B. Anderson's letter dated June 16, 1862 from Cincinnati and addressed to his wife Louisa is written in ink on two sides of a loose sheet of paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 9.0 inches tall (19 x 23 cm) and ruled with horizontal blue lines spaced .33 inches (0.8 cm) apart, except for a 1.5-inch (3.8 cm) unruled top margin. The left edge of the sheet is slightly ragged, while the other three edges are clean, suggesting that the sheet was torn from a notepad or bound notebook. It appears to have been folded in half once. Anderson indicates that this letter written in two seperate sessions. A .5-inch by .5-inch (1.3 x 1.3 cm) embossed printer's mark appears in the upper left- hand corner of the sheet, 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) from the top edge and .25 inch (0.6 cm) from the left edge. Although the mark is indistinct, its shape closely matches that of a distinct, similarly sized and positioned printer's mark on a letter dated July 1, 1863, which reads "MT HOLLY PAPER CO." June 16/62 My DearWife I did not write to you from Louisville on account of our short stay there & thought we would beatbeet the Mail up, we will leave here tonightto night we had a good trip of Coal boat men up here from Louisville but our prospects are poor for a trip of either Freight or passengersPassenger up, though upon the whole we make a paying trip I will finish this half sheet just before we start & then I can tell you more We have laid over and will leave this Evening we are getting all we want I have just been down to see your motherMary Louisa Anderson's mother.. she is not very well Today sends her respects EllaElla is unidentified. was at school I did not see her. There was a large fire down between Third st and The river yesterday just one squaresquear above the old lady's"ladys and burnt a lot of Old Houses & other property we have had all our rooms but 3 in the ladies Cabin full since last night but we have not up till this time had a lady passenger on our boat the old lady says she would like to have you pay her a visit so if you think you would enjoy a trip I will offer you an invitation twe will if no accident get up about Saturday & leave again about Tuesday todayto day it is all most suffocatingly hot and the dust is so thick that I cannot scarcely see the buildings along the wharf & I think we must surely have a gust soon I will stop for I expect to spend Sunday with you & the small ones 4 tell Mary McNamee5 that WM was over with us last evening and that he is well we will leave about 4 or 5 PM this Tuesday EvengEvening Affectionately & Truly Your WBA Mrs. A. T. Stephens 26 Emerson street Newton Massachusetts 94 Similar numbers are penciled under the cancelled postage stamp on several envelopes in the collection [FIGURE OUT PATTERN]. The second number is circled. SEATTLE, WASH. | JUL 6 | 9 - PM | 1909 WORLD'S FAIR SEATTLE Two-cent U.S. postage stamp. U.S. POSTAGE | TWO CENTS [Portrait of Washington; perforated horizontally and vertically; Design A139] Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 27 June 1862. Anderson, William B. USA Columbus, OH Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University William B. Anderson Collection SPEC.RARE.CMS.0309 Anderson tells his wife that his boat's departure has been delayed by a day and asks her to send some food and clothes to him at the dock. He also expresses anxiety about whether his trip will be profitable and asks his wife to request some money from [John?] Russell to help cover an upcoming payday for his crew. William B. Anderson's letter dated June 27, 1862 from Pittsburgh and addressed to his wife Louisa is written in ink on one side of a loose sheet of paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 9.0 inches tall (19 x 23 cm) and ruled with horizontal blue lines spaced .33 inches (0.8 cm) apart, except for a 1.5-inch (3.8 cm) unruled top margin. The left edge of the sheet is slightly ragged, while the other three edges are clean, suggesting that the sheet was torn from a notepad or bound notebook. It appears originally to have been folded once crosswise and twice lengthwise. At this writing, the ink appears brown and the paper off-white (cream). A .5-inch by .5-inch (1.3 x 1.3 cm) embossed printer's mark appears in the upper lefthand corner of the sheet, 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) from the top edge and .25 inches (0.6 cm) from the left edge. Although the mark is indistinct, its shape closely matches that of a distinct, similarly sized and positioned printer's mark on a letter dated July 1, 1863, which reads "MT HOLLY PAPER CO." (see illustrations). Texture? Stiffness? Watermarks? I will have to visit the RBML. June 27/62 Dear Wife I wish to inform you that we are not able to get out till tom =orrow we will not leave here till in the afternoon we are getting a full load or will have a full load before we leave but Prices are low we are anxious to make money and cannot depend upon getting any freight below here. You may send down the Can of milk and 2 Jars of lard and my clothes and overcoat I will bring down and hand to some one on the shore I will hand a note for you to some one on the Shore at Shousetown. 3 I spoke to Russell 4 about Money and you had better Call on him as soon in the week as possible as Saturday is pay day for the hands and he promised to have some let on that you are in great need and you Can fork over to me all you get when I come home Your WB Anderson Mrs. A.
